heading: Metoclopramide
drugs: Metoclopramide
text: With Parkinsonism (risk of exacerbating symptoms). After maximum treatment time of 5 days.

heading: Domperidone
drugs: Domperidone
text:
For treatment other than nausea and vomiting. After maximum treatment time of one week.
In patients with serious underlying heart conditions. If receiving other medications known to prolong QT interval or potent. CYP3A4 inhibitors.

heading: Proton pump inhibitor
drugs: omeprazole, lansoprazole, esomeprazole, famotidine
text: For uncomplicated peptic ulcer disease at full therapeutic dosage after 1-2 months (if healed, offer low dose maintenance treatment, possibly on an ‘as required’ basis - review at least annually)

heading: Drugs likely to cause constipation (e.g. anticholinergic drugs, oral iron, opioids, verapamil, aluminium antacids)
text: In patients with chronic constipation where non-constipating alternatives are available (risk of exacerbation of constipation).

heading: Antimotility drugs
drugs: loperamide hydrochloride, Co-phenotrope, Loperamide hydrochloride and simeticone,
text: Should be AVOIDED if there is blood and mucus in stools or high fever during severe infective gastroenteritis.

heading: Proton pump inhibitor
drugs: omeprazole, lansoprazole, Esomeprazole, pantoprazole, Rabeprazole sodium
text: At full dose, long term (initially 8 weeks, if symptoms resolve consider full dose maintenance, review annually) with severe grade oesophagitis or oesophageal stricture requiring dilation. For patients on medication with risk of gastric bleeding eg. antiplatelets, SSRIs, venlafaxine, corticosteroids, NSAIDs (particularly if in combination where unavoidable)

heading: Fibre supplements ( e.g. bran, isphagula, methylcellulose, sterculia)
drugs: bran, isphagula, methylcellulose, sterculia
text: for diverticulosis with a history of constipation.

heading: Digoxin
drugs: Digoxin
text:
For heart failure with normal systolic ventricular function (no clear evidence of benefit).
For left systolic ventricular dysfunction, where key interventions have not previously been tried (see START). At a long-term dose greater than 125 micrograms/day if eGFR less than 30 ml/min/1.73m2 (risk of toxicity if digoxin plasma levels not measured as eGFR may not be an accurate indicator of clearance).

heading: Thiazide diuretic
drugs:
Bendroflumethiazide, Chlorothiazide,  Chlortalidone, Cyclopenthiazide, 
Hydrochlorothiazide, Indapamide, Metolazone, Polythiazide, Xipamide
text: With current significant hypokalaemia (i.e. serum K+ less than 3.0 mmol/L), hyponatraemia (i.e. serum Na+ less than 130 mmol/L) hypercalcaemia (i.e. corrected serum calcium greater than 2.65 mmol/L) or with recent/ concurrent gout (hypokalaemia, hyponatraemia, hypercalcaemia and gout can be precipitated by thiazide diuretic).

heading: Loop diuretic
drugs: Bumetanide, Furosemide, Torasemide
text: As treatment for hypertension (safer, more effective alternatives available). For dependent ankle oedema without clinical, biochemical evidence or radiological evidence of heart failure, liver failure, nephrotic syndrome or renal failure (leg elevation and/ or compression hosiery usually more appropriate)

heading: Aldosterone antagonists
drugs: spironolactone, eplerenone, Finerenone
text: AIIRAs particularly if co-prescribed with potassium-conserving drugs (e.g. ACEIs, amiloride, triamterene) without monitoring of serum potassium (risk of dangerous hyperkalaemia i.e. greater than 6.0 mmol/L – serum K should be monitored regularly, i.e. at least every 6 months).

heading: Verapamil, diltiazem
drugs: Verapamil, diltiazem
text: With heart failure (may worsen heart failure)

heading: Nicorandil
drugs: Nicorandil
text: If ulceration of the gastro-intestinal tract, skin or mucosa (including eyes) occurs; consider alternative treatment or specialist advice if angina worsens (ulcers caused by Nicorandil do not respond to conventional treatment).

heading: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin-II receptor antagonist
drugs:
Captopril,
Cilazapril,
Co-zidocapt (Hydrochlorothiazide/captopril) ,
Enalapril maleate,
Enalapril maleate with diuretic,
Fosinopril sodium,

Moexipril hydrochloride,

Perindopril arginine with diuretic,
Perindopril erbumine,
Perindopril erbumine with diuretic,
Perindopril tosilate,
Perindopril tosilate/indapamide,
Perindopril with calcium channel blocker,
Quinapril hydrochloride,
Quinapril hydrochloride with diuretic,
Ramipril,
Ramipril with calcium channel blocker,
Trandolapril, 
Trandolapril with calcium channel blocker,
Azilsartan medoxomil,
Candesartan cilexetil,
Eprosartan,
Irbesartan,
Irbesartan with diuretic,
Losartan potassium ,
Losartan potassium with diuretic,
Olmesartan medoxomil,
Olmesartan medoxomil/amlodipine,
Olmesartan medoxomil/amlodipine/hydrochlorothiazide,
Olmesartan medoxomil/hydrochlorothiazide,
Sacubitril/valsartan,
Telmisartan,
Telmisartan with diuretic,
Valsartan,
Valsartan with diuretic
text: In patients with hyperkalaemia. In combination with each other (limited evidence of benefit) – unless under specialist review and recommendation.

heading: Centrally-acting antihypertensives (e.g. methyldopa, clonidine, moxonidine)
drugs: methyldopa, clonidine, moxonidine
text: Unless clear intolerance of, or lack of efficacy with, other classes of antihypertensives (centrally-active antihypertensives are generally less well tolerated by older people than younger people).

heading: Amiodarone
drugs: Amiodarone
text: As first-line antiarrhythmic therapy in supraventricular tachyarrhythmias (higher risk of side-effects than beta-blockers, digoxin, verapamil or diltiazem), following review and recommendation by specialist team.

heading: Non-selective beta-blocker
text: With a recent history of bradycardia, heart block or uncontrolled heart failure; or asthma requiring treatment (risk of increased bronchospasm).

heading: Antihypertensive
text: Where systolic blood pressure consistently above 160 mmHg and/ or diastolic blood pressure consistently above 90 mmHg. If diabetic, if systolic blood pressure above140 mmHg and/ or diastolic blood pressure above 90 mmHg.

drugs:
Amlodipine,

Sotalol hydrochloride,
Timolol ,

text: For stable angina.

drugs:

Atenolol with diuretic,
Bisoprolol fumarate ,

Propranolol hydrochloride with diuretic,
Sotalol hydrochloride,
Timolol ,
Timolol with diuretic,
text: With stable systolic heart failure.

drugs:
Captopril,

Enalapril maleate,

Quinapril hydrochloride,
Quinapril hydrochloride with diuretic,
Ramipril,
Ramipril with calcium channel blocker,
Trandolapril, 
Trandolapril with calcium channel blocker
text: With systolic heart failure and/or documented coronary artery disease.

heading: Statin
drugs:
Atorvastatin,
Fluvastin,
Lovastatin,
Pitavastatin,
Pravastatin,
Rosuvastatin,
Simvastatin,
text: Discussion with patients with known coronary heart disease, QRISK greater than 10%, diabetes type 1 or 2, or CKD with eGFR less than 60 min/1.73m2, consider for 85 years or over . Use Atorvastatin first line.

heading: Aspirin
drugs: Aspirin
text: Long-term aspirin at doses greater than 160 mg per day (increased risk of bleeding, no evidence for increased efficacy). With a past history of peptic ulcer disease without concomitant PPI (risk of recurrent peptic ulcer). In combination with warfarin or NOACs in patients with chronic atrial fibrillation (no added benefit from aspirin). As monotherapy for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation.

heading: Aspirin, clopidogrel, dipyridamole, warfarin or NOACs
drugs:
Aspirin,
Clopidogrel,
Dipyramidole,
Warfarin,
Apixaban, Dabigatran, Rivaroxaban ,  Edoxaban
text: With concurrent significant bleeding risk, i.e. uncontrolled severe hypertension, bleeding diathesis, recent non-trivial spontaneous bleeding (high risk of bleeding).

heading: Aspirin PLUS clopidogrel
drugs: Aspirin, clopidogrel
text: As secondary stroke prevention, unless the patient has a coronary stent(s) inserted in the previous 12 months or concurrent acute coronary syndrome or has a high grade symptomatic carotid arterial stenosis (no evidence of added benefit over clopidogrel monotherapy).

heading: Antiplatelet agents with warfarin or NOACs
drugs:
Aspirin,
Clopidogrel,
Dipyridamole,
Dipyridamole and aspirin ,
Eptifibatide,
Prasugrel,
Ticagrelor,
Ticlopidine hydrochloride ,
Warfarin,
Apixaban, Dabigatran, Rivaroxaban , Edoxaban
text: In patients with stable coronary, cerebrovascular or peripheral arterial disease (No added benefit from dual therapy).

heading: Warfarin or NOACs
drugs:
Warfarin,
Apixaban, Dabigatran, Rivaroxaban , Edoxaban
text: For first deep vein thrombosis without continuing provoking risk factors (e.g.thrombophilia) for longer than 6 months (no proven added benefit). For first pulmonary embolus without continuing provoking risk factors (e.g.thrombophilia) for longer than 12 months (no proven added benefit).

heading: Non steroidal anti-inflammatories PLUS warfarin or NOACs
drugs:
ibuprofen,
naproxen,
diclofenac,
celecoxib,
mefenamic acid,
etoricoxib,
indomethacin,
aspirin,
warfarin,
Apixaban, Dabigatran, Rivaroxaban , Edoxaban
text: In combination (risk of major gastro-intestinal bleeding).

heading: Direct thrombin inhibitors
drugs:
Argatroban,
Bivalirudin ,
Dabigatran
text: If eGFR less than 30 ml/min/1.73m2 (risk of bleeding).

heading: Factor Xa inhibitors
drugs: rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban
text: If eGFR less than 15 ml/min/1.73m2 (risk of bleeding).

heading: Antiplatelet therapy (one of aspirin, clopidogrel, prasugrel or ticagrelor)
drugs: aspirin, clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor
text: With a documented history of coronary, cerebral or peripheral vascular disease.

heading: Anticoagulation (apixaban, edoxaban, warfarin, dabigatran, rivaroxaban)
drugs: apixaban, edoxaban, warfarin, dabigatran, rivaroxaban
text: For atrial fibrillation, using the CHA2DS2-VASc and HAS- BLED score and discuss the risk and benefit with the patient. Offer anticoagulation to people with a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or above (1 or above for males), taking bleeding risk into account. Anticoagulation can be either Warfarin or a NOAC.

heading: Anti-muscarinic bronchodilators
drugs:
Aclidinium Brom/Formoterol,
Aclidinium bromide,
Glycopyrronium bromide,
Ipratropium bromide,
Oxitropium bromide ,
Tiotropium bromide ,
Umeclidinium bromide,
text: With a history of narrow angle glaucoma (may exacerbate glaucoma) or bladder outflow obstruction (may cause urinary retention).

heading: Theophylline
drugs: Theophylline
text: As monotherapy for Asthma or COPD (safer, more effective alternative; risk of adverse effects due to narrow therapeutic index).

heading: Systemic corticosteroids
drugs:
Prednisone,
Prednisolone,
Methylprednisolone,
Beclomethasone,
Betamethasone,
Dexamethasone,
Hydrocortisone,
Triamcinolone
text: Instead of inhaled corticosteroids for maintenance therapy in moderate-severe COPD (unnecessary exposure to long-term side- effects of systemic corticosteroids and effective inhaled therapies are available).

heading: Regular inhaled Beta-2 agonist or antimuscarinic bronchodilator (e.g. ipratropium, aclidinium)
text: For mild to moderate COPD.

heading: Regular inhaled corticosteroid
drugs: Beclometasone dipropionate, Budesonide, Ciclesonide, Fluticasone propionate, Mometasone furoate
text: For moderate-severe asthma or COPD (where FEV1 less than 50% of predicted value and repeated exacerbations requiring treatment with oral corticosteroids). Give a steroid warning card for high doses.

heading: Long term oxygen therapy (LTOT)
text: With documented chronic hypoxaemia - SaO2 less than 92%

heading: Tricyclic antidepressants (TCA) (particularly Dosulepin)
drugs:
Amitriptyline hydrochloride,
Amoxapine,
Clomipramine hydrochloride,
Dosulepin hydrochloride ,
Doxepin,
Imipramine hydrochloride,
Lofepramine hydrochloride,
Maprotiline hydrochloride,
Mianserin hydrochloride ,
Nortriptyline ,
Trazodone hydrochloride ,
Trimipramine maleate,
text:
With dementia (risk of worsening cognitive impairment). With glaucoma (likely to exacerbate glaucoma). With cardiac conductive abnormalities (pro-arrhythmic effects). With constipation or medication likely to exacerbate constipation, following review (likely to worsen constipation).
With prostatism or prior history of urinary retention (risk of urinary retention).

heading: Benzodiazepines or hypnotics
drugs:
diazepam, alprazolam, chlordiazepoxide hydrochloride, clobazam, lorazepam,  oxazepam,
Chloral hydrate,
Clomethiazole ,
Clomethiazole edisilate,
Cloral betaine,
Flurazepam hydrochloride ,
Loprazolam mesilate,
Lormetazepam,
Melatonin,
Midazolam Maleate,
Nitrazepam ,
Other hypnotic preparations,
Sodium oxybate,
Temazepam ,
Triclofos sodium ,
Zaleplon ,
Zolpidem tartrate,
Zopiclone,
text: With acute or chronic respiratory failure i.e. pO2 less than 8.0 kPa and/ or pCO2 greater than 6.5 kPa (risk of exacerbation of respiratory failure). If fallen in past 3 months. For longer than 4 weeks (no indication for longer treatment; risk of prolonged sedation, confusion, impaired balance, falls, road traffic accidents; all benzodiazepines/ hypnotics should be withdrawn gradually if taken for more than 4 weeks as there is a risk of causing a withdrawal syndrome if stopped abruptly).

heading: Antipsychotics
drugs:
misulpride ,
Aripiprazole,
Benperidol,
Cariprazine ,
Chlorpromazine hydrochloride,
Chlorprothixene,
Clozapine ,
Flupentixol hydrochloride,
Fluphenazine hydrochloride,
Haloperidol ,
Levomepromazine hydrochloride,
Levomepromazine maleate ,
Loxapine succinate ,
Lurasidone,
Melperone hydrochloride ,
Olanzapine ,
Paliperidone ,
Pericyazine ,
Perphenazine ,
Pimozide ,
Promazine hydrochloride ,
Quetiapine ,
Risperidone ,
Sulpiride ,
Thioridazine ,
Trifluoperazine,
Ziprasidone hydrochloride,
Zotepine,
Zuclopenthixol acetate ,
Zuclopenthixol hydrochloride,
text: Long-term (i.e. beyond 1 month) as hypnotics (risk of confusion, hypotension, extra-pyramidal side effects, falls). Long-term ( beyond 1 month) in those with Parkinsonism or Lewy Body Disease (likely to worsen extra-pyramidal symptoms). If fallen in past 3 months (may cause gait dyspraxia, Parkinsonism). With moderate –marked antimuscarinic/ anticholinergic effects. (chlorpromazine, clozapine, flupenthixol, flupenzine, pipothiazine, promazine, zuclopenthixol) with a history of prostatism or previous urinary retention (high risk of urinary retention). In patients with behavioural and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD) unless symptoms are severe and other non-pharmacological treatments have failed (increased risk of stroke). As hypnotics, unless sleep disorder is due to psychosis or dementia (risk of confusion, hypotension, extra-pyramidal side –effects, falls).

heading: Levodopa or dopamine agonists
drugs:
Amantadine hydrochloride,
Apomorphine hydrochloride ,
Apomorphine hydrochloride hemihydrate ,
Cabergoline,
Carbidopa ,
Co-beneldopa (Benserazide/levodopa) ,
Co-careldopa (Carbidopa/levodopa) ,
Entacapone ,
Levodopa,
Levodopa/carbidopa/entacapone,
Memantine Hydrochloride,
Opicapone ,
Pergolide mesilate,
Pramipexole ,
Rasagiline mesilate,
Ropinirole hydrochloride ,
Rotigotine,
Safinamide ,
Selegiline hydrochloride ,
Tolcapone ,
text: For benign essential tremor (no evidence of efficacy).

heading: Phenothiazines
drugs: chlorpromazine hydrochloride, fluphenazine decanoate, levomepromazine, pericyazine, prochlorperazine, promazine hydrochloride, trifluoperazine
text: In patients with epilepsy (may lower seizure threshold). As first-line treatment, since safer and more efficacious alternatives exist (phenothiazines are sedative, have significant anti-muscarinic toxicity in older people), with the exception of prochloprerazine for nausea/vomiting/vertigo, chlorpromazine for relief of persistent hiccoughs and levomepromazine as an anti-emetic in palliative care).

heading: Anticholinergic drugs
text:
To treat extra-pyramidal side-effects of antipsychotic medications (risk of anticholinergic toxicity).
In patients with delirium or dementia (risk of exacerbation of cognitive impairment).

heading: Selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors
drugs:
Citalopram hydrobromide,
Duloxetine Hydrochloride ,
Escitalopram,
Fluoxetine hydrochloride ,
Fluvoxamine maleate ,
Paroxetine hydrochloride,
Sertraline hydrochloride,
text: With a history of clinically significant hyponatraemia (below 130 mmol/l within the previous 2 months).

heading: Citalopram and Escitalopram
drugs: Citalopram, Escitalopram
text: With QT-interval prolongation or with concomitant drugs that cause prolonged QT-interval.

heading: First generation antihistamines
drugs: chlorphenamine, cyclizine, promethazine, alimemazine tartrate
text: If prolonged use (longer than 1 week) i.e. chlorphenamine, cyclizine, promethazine (risk of sedation and anti-cholinergic side effects).

heading: Opiates
drugs:
Alfentanil,
Aspirin with codeine,
Bupivacaine with fentanyl,
Buprenorphine,
Buprenorphine with naloxone,
Co-codamol,
Codeine phosphate,
Diamorphine hydrochloride,
Dihydrocodeine tartrate,
Dihydrocodeine with paracetamol,,
Dipipanone hydrochloride with cyclizine,
Hydromorphone hydrochloride,
Meptazinol,
Methadone hydrochloride,
Morphine,
Oxycodone hydrochloride,
Oxycodone with naloxone,
Paracetamol with buclizine hydrochloride and codeine phosphate,
Pentazocine,
Pethidine hydrochloride,
Remifentanil,
Sufentanil,
Tapentadol,
Tramadol hydrochloride,
Tramadol with dexketoprofen,
Tramadol with paracetamol,
text: Use of long-term strong opioids as first line therapy for mild-moderate pain (WHO analgesic ladder not observed). Regular opioids for more than 2 weeks in those with chronic constipation without concurrent use of laxatives (risk of severe constipation). Long-term in those with dementia unless for palliative care or management of chronic pain syndrome (exacerbation of cognitive impairment). Long-term in those with recurrent falls (risk of drowsiness, postural hypotension, vertigo). Slow-release opioids in severe pain without short-acting opioids for break-through pain (risk of persistence of severe pain).

heading: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
drugs:
Captopril,
Cilazapril,
Co-zidocapt (Hydrochlorothiazide/captopril) ,
Enalapril maleate,
Enalapril maleate with diuretic,
Fosinopril sodium,
Imidapril hydrochloride,

Perindopril erbumine,
Perindopril erbumine with diuretic,
Perindopril tosilate,
Perindopril tosilate/indapamide,
Perindopril with calcium channel blocker,
Quinapril hydrochloride,
Quinapril hydrochloride with diuretic,
Ramipril,
Ramipril with calcium channel blocker,
Trandolapril, 
Trandolapril with calcium channel blocker
text: With a known history of persistent bradycardia (below 60 beats/min.), heart block or recurrent unexplained syncope or concurrent treatment with drugs that reduce heart rate such as beta-blockers, digoxin, diltiazem, verapamil (risk of cardiac conduction failure, syncope and injury).

heading: Levodopa or dopamine agonist
drugs:
Amantadine hydrochloride,
Apomorphine hydrochloride ,
Apomorphine hydrochloride hemihydrate ,
Cabergoline,
Carbidopa ,
Co-beneldopa (Benserazide/levodopa) ,

Pramipexole ,
Rasagiline mesilate,
Ropinirole hydrochloride ,
Rotigotine,
Safinamide ,
Selegiline hydrochloride ,
Tolcapone
text: In idiopathic Parkinson’s disease with definite functional impairment and resultant disability.

heading: Antidepressant (non TCA)
drugs:
Isocarboxazid,
Moclobemide,
Phenelzine sulfate,
Tranylcypromine sulfate,
Citalopram hydrobromide,
Duloxetine Hydrochloride ,
Escitalopram,
Fluoxetine hydrochloride ,
Fluvoxamine maleate ,
Paroxetine hydrochloride,
Sertraline hydrochloride,
Agomelatine,
Duloxetine hydrochloride,
Flupentixol hydrochloride,
Mirtazapine,
Nefazodone hydrochloride,
Oxitriptan ,
Reboxetine,
Tryptophan,
Venlafaxine,
Vortioxetine,
text: In the presence of moderate-severe depressive symptoms lasting at least three months (higher risk of adverse drug reactions with TCAs than with SSRIs or SNRIs).

heading: Selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors
drugs:
Citalopram hydrobromide,
Duloxetine Hydrochloride ,
Escitalopram,
Fluoxetine hydrochloride ,
Fluvoxamine maleate ,
Paroxetine hydrochloride,
Sertraline hydrochloride
text: (or SNRI if SSRI is contra-indicated). For persistent severe anxiety that interferes with independent functioning, or for social anxiety disorder where patient declines cognitive behavioural therapy.

heading: Dopamine agonist (ropinirole or pramipexole or rotigotine)
drugs: ropinirole, pramipexole, rotigotine
text: For moderate-severe Restless Legs Syndrome, once iron deficiency and severe renal failure have been excluded and in conjunction with lifestyle measures.

heading: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor
drugs:
Donepezil hydrochloride,
rivastigmine,
Galantamine,
Memantine
text: For mild-moderate Alzheimer’s dementia or Lewy Body dementia (rivastigmine) following review and recommendation by specialist team. Use donepezil first line. (e.g. donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine – or Memantine if others not tolerated)

heading: Strong opioids
drugs:
Alfentanil,
Aspirin with codeine,
Bupivacaine with fentanyl,
Buprenorphine,
Buprenorphine with naloxone,
Co-codamol,
Codeine phosphate,
Diamorphine hydrochloride,
Dihydrocodeine tartrate,
Dihydrocodeine with paracetamol,,
Dipipanone hydrochloride with cyclizine,
Hydromorphone hydrochloride,
Meptazinol,
Methadone hydrochloride,
Morphine,
Oxycodone hydrochloride,
Oxycodone with naloxone,
Paracetamol with buclizine hydrochloride and codeine phosphate,
Pentazocine,
Pethidine hydrochloride,
Remifentanil,
Sufentanil,
Tapentadol,
Tramadol hydrochloride,
Tramadol with dexketoprofen,
Tramadol with paracetamol,"
text: In moderate-severe pain, where paracetamol, NSAIDs or weak opioids are not appropriate to the pain severity or have been ineffective. Use morphine first line.

heading: Sulfonylureas with a long duration of action
drugs: glibenclamide, chlorpropamide, glimepiride
text: With a long duration of action (e.g. glibenclamide, chlorpropamide, glimepiride) with type 2 diabetes mellitus (risk of prolonged hypoglycaemia).

heading: Metformin
drugs: Metformin
text: If eGFR below 30 ml/min/1.73m2 (risk of lactic acidosis).

heading: Pioglitazone
drugs: Pioglitazone
text: In patients with heart failure (risk of exacerbation of heart failure).

heading: Oestrogens
drugs:
Diethylstilbestrol,
Estradiol ,
Estradiol Acetate ,
Estradiol and estriol with progestogen,
Estradiol, estriol and estrone,
Estradiol valerate,
Estradiol with progestogen ,
Estriol,
Estropipate ,
Ethinylestradiol,
Oestrogens conjugated ,
Oestrogens conjugated with bazedoxifene ,
Oestrogens conjugated with progestogen,
Raloxifene hydrochloride,
Tibolone,
text: With a history of breast cancer or venous thromboembolism (increased risk of recurrence). Without progestogen in patients with intact uterus (risk of endometrial cancer).

heading: Any hormone replacement therapy in females
drugs:
Diethylstilbestrol,
Estradiol ,
Estradiol Acetate ,
Estradiol and estriol with progestogen,
Estradiol, estriol and estrone,
Estradiol valerate,
Estradiol with progestogen ,
Estriol,
Estropipate ,
Ethinylestradiol,
Oestrogens conjugated ,
Oestrogens conjugated with bazedoxifene ,
Oestrogens conjugated with progestogen,
Raloxifene hydrochloride,
Tibolone,
text: With:  Acute liver disease (metabolised by the liver). Oestrogen-dependent cancer (may worsen prognosis). Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding or untreated endometrial hyperplasia . Active thrombophlebitis, thrombophilic disorder (increased risk of venous thromboembolism). Active or recent arterial thromboembolic disease (e.g. angina or myocardial Infarction) (at increased risk of arterial thrombosis).

heading: Androgens (male sex hormones)
drugs:
Testosterone,
Testosterone enantate,
Testosterone esters,
Testosterone propionate,
Testosterone undecanoate ,
text: In the absence of primary or secondary hypogonadism (risk of androgen toxicity; no proven benefit outside of the hypogonadism indication).

heading: Bisphosphonates
drugs:
Alendronic acid with colecalciferol,
Ibandronic acid,
Pamidronate disodium,
Risedronate sodium,
Risedronate with calcium carbonate and colecalciferol,
Sodium clodronate,
Zoledronic acid,
text:
If greater than 5 years treatment duration (for drug holiday), after discussion of risks and benefits.
If unexplained thigh, hip or groin pain is reported, after discussion of risks and benefits. Given orally in patients with a current or recent history of upper gastrointestinal disease i.e. dysphagia, oesophagitis, gastritis, duodenitis, or peptic ulcer disease, or upper gastrointestinal bleeding (risk of relapse/exacerbation of oesophagitis, oesophageal ulcer, oesophageal stricture).

drugs:

Denosumab ,

Pamidronate disodium ,
Risedronate sodium ,
Romosozumab ,
Sodium clodronate,
Strontium ranelate ,
Tiludronic acid ,
Zoledronic acid
text: In patients considered at low fracture risk (FRAX ® assessment tool).

heading: Denosumab
drugs: Denosumab
text: If patient is unable to have regular dental check ups.

text: In diabetes with evidence of renal disease i.e. dipstick proteinuria or microalbuminuria (greater than 30 mg/24 hours) with or without serum biochemical renal impairment.

Other vitamin D preparations,

Calcium lactate,
Hydroxyapatite,
Other calcium supplement preparations ,
text: In patients taking long-term systemic glucocorticosteroid therapy (greater than or equal to 7.5 mg prednisolone per day (or equivalent) for 3 months or more).

heading: Vitamin D and calcium (where dietary calcium intake inadequate)
drugs:
Alfacalcidol ,
Calcifediol,

Colecalciferol ,

Ergocalciferol ,
Other vitamin D preparations,
Paricalcitol ,
Calcium carbonate ,

Calcium gluconate ,
Calcium lactate,
Hydroxyapatite,
Other calcium supplement preparations ,
text: Supplement: In patients with known osteoporosis and/or previous fragility fracture(s) and/or (Bone Mineral Density T-scores greater than -2.5 in multiple sites). In older people who are housebound or experiencing falls or with osteopenia (Bone Mineral Density T-score is in the range of -1 to -2.5 in multiple sites).

heading: Bone anti-resorptive or anabolic therapy (e.g. bisphosphonate)
drugs:
Alendronic acid ,
Alendronic acid/colecalciferol ,
Denosumab ,
Etidronate disodium ,
Ibandronic acid ,
Other bisphosphonate and other preparations ,
Pamidronate disodium ,
Risedronate sodium ,
Romosozumab ,
Sodium clodronate,
Strontium ranelate ,
Tiludronic acid ,
Zoledronic acid
text: In patients with documented osteoporosis, where no pharmacological or clinical status contraindication exists (Bone Mineral Density T-scores is less than -2.5 in multiple sites) and/or previous history of fragility fracture(s).

heading: Alpha1-receptor blocker
drugs:
Alfuzosin hydrochloride,
Doxazosin,
Indoramin,
Prazosin,
Tamsulosin with dutasteride,
Tamsulosin with solifenacin,
Terazosin,
text: In those with symptomatic orthostatic hypotension or micturition syncope (risk of precipitating recurrent syncope).

heading: Anticholinergic drugs
text: Dementia, or chronic cognitive impairment (risk of increased confusion, agitation), narrow-angle glaucoma (risk of acute exacerbation of glaucoma), chronic prostatism (risk of urinary retention).

heading: Phosphodiesterase type-5 inhibitors
drugs:
sildenafil,
 Avanafil,
Tadalafil,
Vardenafil,
text: In severe heart failure characterised by hypotension i.e. systolic BP below 90 mmHg, or concurrent nitrate therapy for angina (risk of cardiovascular collapse).

spironolactone, eplerenone, Finerenone, Amiloride hydrochloride, Triamterene, Amiloride hydrochloride with loop diuretics,

text: For symptomatic atrophic vaginitis.

drugs:

Prazosin,

Tamsulosin with solifenacin,
Terazosin,
text: With symptomatic prostatism, where prostatectomy is not considered necessary.

drugs: finasteride, Dutasteride, Tamsulosin with dutasteride

Polysaccharide-iron complex ,
Sodium feredetate ,
text: Greater than 200 mg daily e.g. ferrous fumarate above 600 mg/day, ferrous sulphate above 600 mg/day, ferrous gluconate above 1800.

heading: NSAID
drugs:
Aceclofenac,
Acemetacin ,
Azapropazone ,
Benorilate ,
Celecoxib ,
Dexketoprofen ,
Diclofenac potassium,
Diclofenac sodium ,
Diflunisal,
Etodolac,
Etoricoxib ,
Fenbufen,
Fenoprofen ,
Flurbiprofen,
Ibuprofen,

Ibuprofen sodium dihydrate,
Indometacin ,
Ketoprofen,
Lornoxicam ,
Lumiracoxib ,
Mefenamic acid ,
Meloxicam ,
Nabumetone,
Naproxen ,
Naproxen sodium,
Phenylbutazone,
Piroxicam,
Rofecoxib ,
Sulindac ,
Tenoxicam ,
Tiaprofenic acid,
text: With history of peptic ulcer disease or gastrointestinal bleeding, unless with concurrent, appropriate gastroprotection (risk of peptic ulcer relapse). With concurrent oral corticosteroid, antiplatelet (especially Aspirin) or antidepressant (SSRI, Venlafaxine) without concurrent, appropriate gastroprotection (increased risk of peptic ulcer disease). With severe or uncontrolled hypertension (risk of exacerbation of hypertension). With moderate-severe heart failure (risk of exacerbation of heart failure). Do not use Diclofenac or a COX-2 selective agent at any stage of heart failure. Long-term (beyond 3 months) for symptom relief of musculoskeletal pain where simple analgesia and/ or topical NSAID (where appropriate) has not been tried (may be as effective for pain relief). If eGFR less than 50 ml/min/1.73m2 (risk of deterioration in renal function). With warfarin or NOAC (risk of gastrointestinal bleeding).

text: For chronic treatment of gout where there is no contraindication to Allopurinol (xanthine-oxidase inhibitors are first choice prophylactic drugs in gout)(beyond 3 months).

drugs: Colchicine
text: If eGFR less than 10 ml/min/1.73m2 (risk of colchicine toxicity).

heading: Quinine
drugs: Quinine
text: Take a trial break every three months, unless leg cramps are painful and cause regular disruption of sleep. If no benefit after four weeks.

drugs: Allopurinol
text: With a history of recurrent episodes of gout.
